diseases.summary: Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, is a benign tumor that develops on the nerve connecting the ear and brain.
Tonsillitis is an inflammation (swelling) of the tonsils, sometimes occurring along with swollen adenoids.
risk_factors: Being a child over age two
Being a child ages 5-15 (for bacterial tonsillitis)
Being a younger child (for viral tonsillitis)
symptoms: White or yellow coating on tonsils
diagnosis: Assessment of symptoms and medical history
Physical examination of throat and neck

diseases.summary: Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) is a rare type of cancer that can occur in various body sites, most commonly in the salivary glands. It is the third-most common malignant salivary gland tumor overall and the most common malignant salivary gland tumor in the submandibular region. ACC is generally well-differentiated and slow-growing, allowing patients to survive for years with metastases, though late-occurring metastatic disease can be fatal.
causes: Gene fusion of MYB with the NFIB gene
MYB activation by copy number gain
MYB activation by enhancer element juxtaposition
diagnosis: MRI-images analyzed following nerve tracts up to the brainstem

diseases.summary: Adrenal cancer is a rare cancer that begins in the adrenal glands, which are located on top of the kidneys.

Adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) is an aggressive cancer originating in the cortex of the adrenal gland. It is a rare tumor with a bimodal age distribution, affecting children under 5 and adults aged 30-40. ACC can cause various hormonal syndromes and often invades nearby tissues or metastasizes at diagnosis.
causes: Inherited inactivation mutation in TP53 (Li-Fraumeni syndrome)
diagnosis: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen
Weiss system for differentiating from adrenocortical adenoma

diseases.summary: Anal cancer is a cancer that forms in the tissues of the anus, the opening at the end of the large intestine where stool leaves the body. It is typically a squamous cell carcinoma, but other types include adenocarcinoma, small cell carcinoma, and melanoma.
causes: Remnant of the cloacal membrane of the embryo (cloacogenic carcinoma)
symptoms: Bleeding from the anus or rectum
Pain or pressure in the anus or rectum
Itchiness or discharge from the anus
treatments: Infrared photocoagulation (for carcinoma-in-situ and anal intraepithelial neoplasia)

diseases.summary: Anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC) is an aggressive and uncommon form of thyroid cancer characterized by the uncontrolled growth of highly abnormal cells in the thyroid gland. It accounts for a small percentage of thyroid cancer cases but is responsible for a disproportionately high number of deaths due to its aggressive behavior and resistance to treatments. ATC often dedifferentiates from pre-existing differentiated thyroid cancer, leading to poor prognosis and a median survival time of a few months.
risk_factors: Repeated radiation exposure to the chest or neck
Exposure to radiation treatments to head or neck as a child
Certain genetic conditions (e.g., multiple endocrine neoplasia)
Family history of thyroid cancer or thyroid disease
symptoms: Redness and swelling of overlying skin
Symptoms from distant metastases (e.g., to the brain)
diagnosis: Immunohistochemistry testing (keratin, p53, PAX8 positive; thyroid transcription factor-1, thyroglobulin, calcitonin negative)
Physical exam (checking neck for swelling, lumps)
Ultrasound imaging (hypoechoic mass with invasion of local structures)
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the neck (if surgery planned)
CT scan of neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis (if PET unavailable)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain (to assess for distant metastases)
treatments: Targeted therapy (e.g., BRAF and MEK inhibitors like dabrafenib and trametinib, vemurafenib and cobimetinib)

diseases.summary: Angiosarcoma is a rare and aggressive cancer that starts in the endothelial cells that line the walls of blood vessels or lymphatic vessels. It can appear anywhere and at any age, but older people are more commonly affected, and the skin is the most affected area. Multiple-organ involvement at time of diagnosis is common.
causes: Damage to the DNA of endothelial cells
risk_factors: AIDS (potential link, may be misdiagnosed Kaposi's sarcoma)
Male sex (for liver and cutaneous angiosarcoma)

diseases.summary: Appendix cancer is a very rare malignant tumor that forms in the vermiform appendix. It can include carcinoid tumors, mucinous adenocarcinomas, adenocarcinoma not otherwise specified (NOS), and signet ring cell adenocarcinoma. Other malignancies can metastasize to the appendix, including breast cancer, colon cancer, and tumors of the female genital tract. Primary lymphomas can also occur in the appendix.
causes: Metastasis from tumors of the female genital tract
risk_factors: Neuroendocrine tumor (NET) of the intestines (for carcinoid tumors)
Being female (minor prevalence for neuroendocrine tumors)
Being Caucasian (minor prevalence for neuroendocrine tumors)
treatments: Appendectomy (for small neuroendocrine tumors <2 cm without malignancy features)
Right hemicolectomy (for other neuroendocrine tumors and adenocarcinomas)

diseases.summary: Astroblastoma is a rare glial tumor derived from the astroblast, a type of cell that closely resembles spongioblastoma and astrocytes. It is most likely found in the supratentorial region of the brain, including the cerebrum, frontal lobe, parietal lobe, and temporal lobe, but can also occur in other brain areas. It accounts for a small percentage of all brain gliomas and is considered challenging to diagnose and treat.
diagnosis: Immunohistochemistry (GFAP, vimentin, NSE, synaptophysin, neurofilament, TUJ1, nestin)
treatments: Chemotherapy (nimustine hydrochloride (ACNU), etoposide, vincristine, interferon-beta, ifosfamide, cisplatin, temozolomide)
Radiotherapy (Conventional external beam radiation, CyberKnife radiotherapy, Gamma Knife radiosurgery)

diseases.summary: Astrocytoma is a type of brain tumor originating from astrocytes, a type of glial cell in the cerebrum. It typically does not spread outside the brain and spinal cord. Astrocytomas are the second most common type of glioma after glioblastomas and can occur in most parts of the brain and occasionally the spinal cord. They are classified into two broad classes: those with narrow zones of infiltration (mostly noninvasive) and those with diffuse zones of infiltration (high-grade).
causes: Genome-wide pattern of DNA copy-number alterations (CNAs)
diagnosis: Histopathological and molecular findings (current WHO criteria)
Neurological exam (vision, balance, coordination, mental status)
Biopsy (tissue removal for examination and grading)
Grading of tumor sample (WHO grading system)

synonyms: Malignant rhabdoid tumor of the CNS
diseases.summary: A rare, aggressive tumor usually diagnosed in childhood, most commonly occurring in the central nervous system (CNS), including the brain and spinal cord. It is characterized by specific genetic alterations, particularly involving the INI1/hSNF5 gene.
causes: Germline genetic mutations in the INI1/hSNF5 gene
Biallelic inactivation of the INI1/hSNF5 tumor suppressor gene
risk_factors: Family history of rhabdoid tumors or other CNS tumors
Presence of germline mutations in the INI1 gene
symptoms: Abnormal feeling in the legs (spinal tumors)
diagnosis: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and spine
Computed tomography (CT) of chest and abdomen
Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis
Cytological or genetic analysis of tumor tissue
Genetic analysis for INI1/hSNF5 gene deletion or mutation
treatments: Chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatinum, carboplatinum, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, etoposide, intrathecal mafosfamide)
Radiation therapy (external beam, conformal, proton beam)
High dose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue
subtypes: Malignant rhabdoid tumor (MRT) of the kidney (closely related)

diseases.summary: Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that begins in the basal cells, which are in the lower part of the epidermis. It is the most common type of skin cancer.
risk_factors: Certain genetic syndromes (e.g., Gorlin syndrome, Xeroderma pigmentosum)
symptoms: A flat, flesh-colored or brown scar-like lesion
A sore that bleeds and scabs over, then returns

diseases.summary: Bile duct cancer, also known as cholangiocarcinoma, is a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts. The bile ducts are small tubes that carry bile from the liver and gallbladder to the small intestine.
causes: Certain inherited conditions (e.g., Lynch syndrome, cystic fibrosis)
risk_factors: Chronic inflammation of the bile ducts
symptoms: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
diagnosis: Imaging tests (e.g., ultrasound, CT scan, MRI, ERCP)

diseases.summary: Bile duct cancer, also known as cholangiocarcinoma, is a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts. The bile ducts are small tubes that carry bile from the liver and gallbladder to the small intestine.
risk_factors: Family history of bile duct cancer
symptoms: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
diagnosis: Imaging tests (e.g., CT scan, MRI, ultrasound)

diseases.summary: Bile duct cancer, also known as cholangiocarcinoma, is a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts. The bile ducts are small tubes that carry bile from the liver and gallbladder to the small intestine.
symptoms: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
diagnosis: Imaging tests (e.g., CT scan, MRI, ultrasound)

diseases.summary: Bile duct cancer, also known as cholangiocarcinoma, is a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts. The bile ducts are small tubes that carry bile from the liver and gallbladder to the small intestine.
diagnosis: Imaging tests (e.g., CT scan, MRI, ultrasound)

synonyms: Transitional cell cancer of the bladder
diseases.summary: Bladder cancer is the abnormal growth of cells in the bladder, which can form tumors that spread and damage organs. It is the tenth most commonly diagnosed cancer and thirteenth cause of cancer deaths globally. Risk increases with age, and tobacco smoking is the greatest contributor.
causes: Exposure to aromatic amines (benzidine, beta-naphthylamine, ortho-toluidine)
Mutations in the PTEN gene (Cowden disease)
Mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (Lynch syndrome)
Variants in genes involved in carcinogen metabolism (NAT2, GSTM1, UGT1A6)
Variants in genes controlling cell growth (TP63, CCNE1, MYC, FGFR3)
Variants in DNA repair genes (NBN, XRCC1, XRCC3, ERCC2, ERCC4, ERCC5)
symptoms: No symptoms (tumors detected during unrelated imaging)
Pain and swelling around lymph nodes (abdomen or groin)
diagnosis: Physical examination (digital rectal exam, pelvic exam)
Urine tests for bladder tumor antigen (BTA)
Urine tests for mRNA of tumor-associated genes
Ultrasound of the upper urinary tract
treatments: Intravesical chemotherapy (mitomycin C, gemcitabine, docetaxel, valrubicin)
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (gemcitabine plus cisplatin; methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin)
COX-2 inhibitor drugs (piroxicam, deracoxib, meloxicam) in dogs

synonyms: Cancer of the Bone and Joint
diseases.summary: Bone cancer is a type of cancer that begins in any bone of the body. It can start in the cells that make up bone, or in cells that grow on or around bones, such as cartilage, fat, or muscle. Bone cancer can also start in other parts of the body and spread to the bone. This is called metastatic bone cancer or secondary bone cancer.
risk_factors: Inherited genetic syndromes (e.g., Li-Fraumeni syndrome, hereditary retinoblastoma)

diseases.summary: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a type of chronic leukemia where the bone marrow makes abnormal lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). These abnormal cells crowd out healthy cells, leading to infection, anemia, and easy bleeding. The abnormal cells can also spread outside the blood to other parts of the body. CLL usually gets worse slowly and is one of the most common types of leukemia in adults, often occurring during or after middle age.
causes: Changes in the genetic material (DNA) in bone marrow cells
risk_factors: Family history of CLL and other blood and bone marrow diseases
Exposure to certain chemicals, including Agent Orange
symptoms: Pain or fullness below the ribs
diagnosis: Blood tests (complete blood count with differential, blood chemistry tests)
treatments: Chemotherapy with bone marrow or stem cell transplant

diseases.summary: A brain tumor is a growth of abnormal cells in the tissues of the brain. They can be benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous). Primary brain tumors start in the brain, while secondary (metastatic) tumors spread from elsewhere in the body. Symptoms vary based on size, location, and growth rate, and can include headaches, seizures, vision problems, vomiting, mental changes, difficulty with movement or speech, and behavioral changes. Diagnosis typically involves medical examination, imaging (MRI, CT scans), and biopsy. Treatment may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and targeted therapy.
causes: Genetic mutations activating oncogenes or deactivating tumor suppressor genes (e.g., TP53, IDH1, IDH2)
Exposure to ionizing radiation (including CT scan radiation)
Inherited syndromes (e.g., neurofibromatosis, tuberous sclerosis, von Hippel-Lindau Disease, multiple endocrine neoplasia, neurofibromatosis type 2)
risk_factors: Mobile phone radiation (classified as possibly carcinogenic, Group 2B by WHO)
symptoms: Headaches (often in the morning, worse with Valsalva maneuver, awakening from sleep, progressively worsening, atypical features)
Difficulty with writing, drawing, naming, and recognizing
Poor vision or loss of vision
diagnosis: Genetic and chromosomal testing (e.g., for IDH1, IDH2, TP53, ATRX, EGFR, TERT, PTEN mutations, 1p/19q co-deletion)
treatments: Surgery (complete or partial resection, gross total resection, cytoreduction, trans-nasal, trans-sphenoidal approach, craniotomy)

Radiation therapy (external beam radiation therapy, radiosurgery, stereotactic radiosurgery, Gamma knife, Cyberknife, Novalis Tx radiosurgery, whole-brain radiotherapy treatment (WBRT), brachytherapy, proton therapy)
Targeted therapy (e.g., anti-VEGFA antibody like Bevacizumab)

diseases.summary: Breast cancer is a cancer that develops from breast tissue, characterized by uncontrolled cell growth. It can manifest as a lump, changes in breast shape, skin dimpling, nipple inversion, or discharge. Advanced stages can lead to bone pain, swollen lymph nodes, shortness of breath, or jaundice. It is the most common invasive cancer in women globally and can also affect men.
causes: Overexpression of leptin in breast adipose tissue
Mutations in DNA repair mechanisms (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2, p53, PTEN)
risk_factors: Late age at first childbirth or nulliparity
Exposure to certain chemicals (polychlorinated biphenyls, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, organic solvents)
Radiation therapy to the breast or chest before age 30
symptoms: Red or scaly patch of skin
Swelling or pain in the breast
Pain or inversion of the nipple
Swelling of lymph nodes under the arms or along the collar bone
Warm, red, and swollen breast (inflammatory breast cancer)
Eczema-like red, scaly irritation on the nipple and areola (Paget's disease of the breast)
Disruptions to speech, vision, memory, and behavior (with brain metastases)
treatments: Surgery (mastectomy, lumpectomy, breast-conserving surgery, partial mastectomy)
Targeted therapy (HER2-targeted therapies, alpelisib, capivasertib, PARP inhibitors)
Supportive care (antiemetic drugs, cold caps, antidepressants, physical therapy, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, counseling, personal lubricants)

diseases.summary: Carcinoid syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome comprising the signs and symptoms that occur secondary to neuroendocrine tumors. It is caused by these tumors releasing biologically active substances into the blood.
causes: Release of biologically active substances (serotonin, histamine, tachykinins, kallikrein, prostaglandins) by neuroendocrine tumors
Metastasis of neuroendocrine tumors to the liver allowing substances to bypass first pass metabolism
Neuroendocrine tumors arising in the bronchi releasing products into systemic circulation before liver metabolism
risk_factors: Neuroendocrine tumors that have metastasized to the liver
symptoms: Fibrosis of the tricuspid and pulmonic valves
diagnosis: Nuclear medicine gamma camera imaging (indium-111 pentetreotide)
treatments: Surgical valve repair or replacement (carcinoid heart disease)

diseases.summary: Carcinoid tumors are a type of neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the body, most commonly in the gastrointestinal tract and lungs. They are typically slow-growing but can spread to other parts of the body. Carcinoid syndrome is a condition associated with some carcinoid tumors that release hormones.
causes: Genetic mutations (implicit in 'What Causes Gastrointestinal Carcinoid Tumors')
risk_factors: Family history (implicit in risk factor sections)
treatments: Treatment based on extent of disease

diseases.summary: Carcinosarcomas are rare malignant tumors composed of a mixture of carcinoma and sarcoma, which can arise in various organs.
causes: Early alteration in histogenesis with late transformation/degeneration of epithelial component into sarcomatous component
Identical p53 mutations in epithelial and mesenchymal components
Identical KRAS mutations in epithelial and mesenchymal components

diseases.summary: Castleman disease (CD) is a group of rare lymphoproliferative disorders characterized by enlarged lymph nodes, a broad range of inflammatory symptoms, and laboratory abnormalities. It can involve one or more enlarged lymph nodes in a single region (unicentric CD, UCD) or multiple enlarged lymph node regions (multicentric CD, MCD).
causes: Genetic change in lymph node tissue (UCD)
diagnosis: Microscopic analysis of lymph node tissue (histology)
Staining for latency-associated nuclear antigen (LANA-1) for HHV-8 infection
Imaging (MRI, CT, or ultrasound) for organ involvement

diseases.summary: Cervical cancer is a type of cancer that develops in the cervix, the lower, narrow end of the uterus that opens into the vagina. It is caused by abnormal cell growth that can invade or spread to other parts of the body. Early stages are often asymptomatic, but later symptoms can include abnormal vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or pain during sexual intercourse. The vast majority of cases are linked to persistent genital human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.
risk_factors: Starting sex at a young age
Having partners with many sexual partners
symptoms: Abnormal vaginal bleeding (e.g., after sex, between periods)
Vaginal discharge (watery, strong odor, or bloody)
Leakage of urine or feces from the vagina

diseases.summary: Chordoma is a rare, slow-growing cancer that originates from cellular remnants of the notochord, typically found in the skull base and spine. It is a type of bone cancer classified as a sarcoma, and while sometimes mistaken for brain or spinal cord tumors due to its location, it does not arise from nervous tissue.
causes: Duplication of the brachyury gene (familial form)
treatments: Radiation therapy (proton therapy, carbon ion therapy)

diseases.summary: Choriocarcinoma is a trophoblastic cancer that usually originates in the placenta. It is characterized by early hematogenous spread to the lungs and is considered the malignant end of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD). It can also arise in the testis or ovary as a germ cell tumor.
causes: Trophoblastic components in mixed germ cell tumors
diagnosis: Identification of syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts without placental villi
Elevated blood levels of beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG)
treatments: Chemotherapy (single-agent methotrexate or actinomycin-D for low-risk disease)
Combination chemotherapy regimens (EMACO: etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, vincristine for intermediate or high-risk disease)
Hysterectomy (for patients >40 years or those for whom sterilization is not an obstacle, or with severe infection and uncontrolled bleeding)
Chemotherapy (less effective for testicular or ovarian choriocarcinoma)

diseases.summary: Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a cancer of the white blood cells, specifically a type of chronic leukemia characterized by the increased and unregulated growth of myeloid cells in the bone marrow and their accumulation in the blood. It is a clonal bone marrow stem cell disorder associated with the Philadelphia chromosome, a characteristic chromosomal translocation.
causes: Genetic change called the Philadelphia chromosome
BCR-ABL fusion gene creating an abnormal protein that allows leukemia cells to grow out of control
symptoms: Weight loss for no known reason
Pain or a feeling of fullness below the ribs on the left side
diagnosis: Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) for BCR-ABL1
treatments: High-dose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant

diseases.summary: Clear cell sarcoma is a rare sub-type of sarcoma that mainly occurs in soft tissues and the dermis. It presents as a slow-growing mass, often affecting tendons and aponeuroses, and is typically found in the extremities, particularly around the knee, feet, and ankle. Patients are usually between 20 and 40 years old. Recurrence is common, and metastasis can occur in over 50% of cases.
subtypes: Clear cell sarcoma of the soft tissues
Clear cell sarcoma of the kidney

diseases.summary: Colorectal cancer is a cancer that develops in the tissues of the colon or rectum, which are parts of the large intestine. It is caused by uncontrolled growth of colon cells that can invade and spread to other parts of the body. It often starts as a benign polyp and can be diagnosed through colonoscopy and medical imaging. Screening is effective for prevention and reducing deaths.
causes: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Field defects (preconditioned epithelium prone to cancer development)
risk_factors: Personal or family history of colorectal cancer
Genetic syndromes (familial adenomatous polyposis, Lynch syndrome)
Alcohol consumption (three or more drinks per day)
symptoms: Blood in the stool (bright red or very dark)
Change in bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, feeling of incomplete bowel emptying, narrower stool)
Weight loss for no known reason
diagnosis: Medical imaging (CT scan, PET scan, MRI)
Stool tests (fecal occult blood testing, fecal immunochemical testing, stool DNA screening)
Histopathology (adenocarcinoma, lymphoma, adenosquamous, squamous cell carcinoma)
treatments: Surgery (endoscopic mucosal resection, endoscopic submucosal dissection, partial colectomy, proctocolectomy, cytoreductive surgery)
Chemotherapy (fluorouracil, capecitabine, oxaliplatin, irinotecan, UFT, CAPOX, FOLFOX, FOLFOXIRI, FOLFIRI)

diseases.summary: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) is a class of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, a cancer of the immune system caused by mutations of T cells. These cancerous T cells migrate to the skin, causing lesions that can progress from rashes to plaques and tumors.
risk_factors: Infection with Polyomaviruses (e.g., Merkel cell polyomavirus)
diagnosis: Point-based algorithm for diagnosis of early forms of CTCL (International Society for Cutaneous Lymphomas, 2005)

diseases.summary: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a rare, locally aggressive malignant cutaneous soft-tissue sarcoma that develops in the connective tissue cells of the dermis. It is characterized by slow growth, a high rate of local recurrence, and a low metastatic potential. DFSP can resemble a bruise, birthmark, or pimple and is often found on the torso, but can occur anywhere on the body.
causes: Chromosomal translocation t(17;22) fusing COL1A1 and PDGF genes
risk_factors: Older age (most often arise in patients in their thirties, possibly due to diagnostic delay)
symptoms: Can resemble a bruise, birthmark, or pimple
diagnosis: Immunohistochemical stains (CD34, S-100 protein, factor XIIIa, estrogen and progesterone receptors)
Genetic and chromosomal testing (for t(17;22) translocation)
treatments: Surgical treatment (Mohs micrographic surgery, Wide local excision)

diseases.summary: Benign tumors are abnormal growths in the body that are not cancerous. They grow only in one place and cannot spread or invade other parts of the body. However, they can be dangerous if they press on vital organs. Tumors are made up of extra cells that divide without stopping.
causes: Cells grow old and die, and new cells take their place. Sometimes, this process goes wrong. New cells form when your body does not need them, and old cells do not die when they should.
subtypes: Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis or Laryngeal Papillomatosis

diseases.summary: Embryonal carcinoma is a type of nonseminomatous germ cell tumor that can occur in the ovaries and testes. It is characterized by cells that are attempting to evolve into their next stage of development. In the testis, it often presents as a component of mixed germ cell tumors.
diagnosis: Gross examination showing pale grey, poorly defined tumor with hemorrhage and necrosis
Microscopic features: indistinct cell borders, mitoses, variable architecture (tubulopapillary, glandular, solid, embryoid bodies), nuclear overlap, necrosis
Predominant architectural patterns: Solid, glandular, papillary
Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels (elevated levels more suggestive of yolk sac tumor)
Serum human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels (in association with other tumors)
Distinguishing from seminoma, teratocarcinoma, yolk sac tumor, and Sertoliâ€“Leydig cell tumor
subtypes: Childhood Undifferentiated Embryonal Sarcoma of the Liver

diseases.summary: Thymus cancer refers to cancers that originate in the thymus gland, a small organ located behind the breastbone. This category includes thymoma and thymic carcinoma.
diagnosis: CECT-based simplified scoring model for differentiating low-risk thymomas from hyper-attenuating thymic
Integrative radiomics of intra- and peri-tumoral features for enhanced risk prediction

diseases.summary: Endometrial cancer is a cancer that arises from the endometrium, the lining of the uterus. It is characterized by abnormal cell growth that can invade or spread to other parts of the body. It is the most common type of uterine cancer and primarily affects women after menopause.
causes: Genetic mutations (e.g., in PTEN, TP53, MLH1, MLH2, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, ARID1A, PIK3CA, KRAS, CTNNB1, FGFR2, SPOP)
risk_factors: Black women (in the US, for Type II)
Trans men on testosterone without hysterectomy
Higher circulating testosterone levels in women
symptoms: Vaginal bleeding not associated with a menstrual period
Vaginal bleeding or spotting after menopause
Extremely long, heavy, or frequent episodes of bleeding (pre-menopause)
Thin white or clear vaginal discharge (postmenopausal women)
diagnosis: Cervical screening test (Pap smear - not typically sufficient)
treatments: Abdominal hysterectomy (total removal of the uterus)
Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (removal of Fallopian tubes and ovaries)
Hormone therapy (progestins, tamoxifen, megestrol acetate, medroxyprogesterone, letrozole, anastrozole)
Targeted therapy (e.g., Dostarlimab, PARP inhibitors like olaparib, mTOR inhibitors like temsirolimus, ridaforolimus, bevacizumab, tyrosine kinase inhibitors, ixabepilone)
Bone marrow or stem cell transplant (not explicitly mentioned for endometrial cancer, but a general cancer treatment)

diseases.summary: Ependymoma is a tumor that arises from the ependyma, a tissue of the central nervous system. It can occur in the brain or spinal cord, with common locations including the floor of the fourth ventricle and the lumbosacral region. Ependymomas are classified by location, cellular features, and molecular characteristics, with grades ranging from I to III.
symptoms: Seeing vertical or horizontal lines when in bright light
Numbness or weakness in the limbs

diseases.summary: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma (EHE) is a rare vascular cancer that is intermediate between angiosarcoma and hemangioma, but genetically distinct. It is a soft tissue sarcoma originating from endothelial cells and can occur in organs throughout the body, most frequently in the liver, lungs, bones, and skin. EHE typically has an indolent course, but can occasionally present as high-grade and aggressive.
causes: Balanced, reciprocal translocation t(1;3)(p36.3;q25) leading to TAZ-CAMTA1 fusion gene
Fusion gene resulting in constitutively active TAZ protein
Constitutive activation of YAP (orthologue of TAZ) due to a different translocation in ~10% of patients
diagnosis: Genetic testing for specific translocations (e.g., t(1;3)(p36.3;q25))
treatments: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sorafenib, sunitinib, pazopanib)
Multi-agent chemotherapy (for aggressive or unresponsive cases)

diseases.summary: Esophageal cancer is a group of cancers that affect the esophagus, the tube that connects the throat to the stomach. It is the eighth most frequently diagnosed cancer worldwide and a significant cause of cancer-related deaths. The prognosis is generally poor due to late presentation with advanced disease. Two main types are esophageal squamous-cell carcinoma (ESCC) and esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC).
risk_factors: Geographical location (e.g., Asian esophageal cancer belt for ESCC, Western countries for EAC)
diagnosis: Imaging (MRI, CT, or ultrasound) for organ involvement
Imaging (MRI, CT, or ultrasound) for organ involvement
treatments: Chemotherapy (cisplatin-based, carboplatin, oxaliplatin, fluorouracil, capecitabine, epirubicin, nivolumab, pembrolizumab)
Endoscopic therapy (for stage 0 and I disease)

diseases.summary: Head and neck cancer is a term for cancers that develop in the mouth, nose and sinuses, salivary glands, and throat and voice box (larynx). Most head and neck cancers are squamous cell cancers, which begin in the moist tissues lining the head and neck. The cancer cells can spread into deeper tissue as the cancer grows.
causes: HPV infection (for cancers in the tonsils and base of the tongue)
Exposure to wood dusts or certain other toxic substances at work (for upper throat, nose, and sinus cancers)
Radiation exposure to the head and neck (for salivary gland cancer)
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection (for upper throat and salivary gland cancers)
risk_factors: History of head or neck cancer
symptoms: Sore in the mouth or throat that does not heal and may be painful
Sore throat that does not go away
Change or hoarseness in the voice
diagnosis: Biopsy or other procedure to collect cells

diseases.summary: Ewing sarcoma is a type of pediatric cancer that forms in bone or soft tissue, most commonly in the legs, pelvis, and chest wall. It is a small round cell sarcoma that affects teenagers and young adults, and is the second most common bone cancer in children and adolescents.
causes: Reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11;22), which fuses the EWSR1 gene with the FLI1 gene
Genetic change known as a reciprocal translocation
risk_factors: Older age at diagnosis (older than 18 years of age)
symptoms: Swelling at the site of the tumor
Pain at the site of the tumor
diagnosis: Conventional radiographs (moth-eaten pattern, Codman triangle, onion peel appearance)
treatments: Multidrug chemotherapy (vincristine, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, ifosfamide, etoposide)
Local disease control with radiation therapy

diseases.summary: Eye cancer refers to cancers that start in or spread to the eye. There are several types of eye cancer, including intraocular melanoma and retinoblastoma.

Primary fallopian tube cancer is a malignant neoplasm that originates from the fallopian tube. It is grouped under epithelial ovarian cancers and shares similarities and treatments with ovarian and primary peritoneal cancers.
symptoms: Pain in the abdomen or pelvis
Swelling in the abdomen or pelvis
Feeling of pressure in the abdomen or pelvis
Sudden or frequent urge to urinate
A lump in the pelvic area
diagnosis: Medical imaging (transvaginal ultrasound, abdominal ultrasound, CT scan, MRI)
Pathologic assessment of fallopian tissue (SEE-FIM Protocol)
Pelvic mass detection on routine gynecologic examination
treatments: Surgery (total abdominal hysterectomy, removal of ovaries, tubes, uterus, cervix, omentum removal, lymph node sampling)

diseases.summary: Fibrosarcoma is a malignant mesenchymal tumor derived from fibrous connective tissue, characterized by immature proliferating fibroblasts or undifferentiated anaplastic spindle cells in a storiform pattern. It can arise in fibrous tissues of bone, invades long or flat bones, and involves the periosteum and overlying muscle. It can also occur in infants, often congenitally, and in animals like dogs and cats.
causes: Translocation between chromosomes 12 and 15 (t(12;15)(p13;q25)) resulting in ETV6-NTRK3 fusion gene (in infantile type)
Trisomy for chromosomes 8, 11, 17, or 20 (in infantile type)
diagnosis: IHC (vimentin positive, cytokeratin negative, S100 negative, actin variable)

diseases.summary: Gallbladder cancer is a relatively uncommon cancer that is thought to be related to the formation of gallstones. It is often diagnosed late, after symptoms such as abdominal pain, jaundice, and vomiting appear, and has a poor prognosis. Most tumors are adenocarcinomas.
causes: Congenital abnormalities of the bile duct (e.g., choledochal cyst)
risk_factors: Living in central and South America, central and eastern Europe, Japan, and northern India
treatments: Removal of part of the liver (hepatectomy)

diseases.summary: Stomach cancer, also known as gastric cancer, refers to cancer that develops in the stomach. It can affect any part of the stomach and may spread to other organs. The provided text lists various resources for understanding symptoms, diagnosis, treatment, and research related to stomach cancer.
risk_factors: Dietary factors (not explicitly detailed but implied by nutrition counseling)

diseases.summary: Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is a group of rare pregnancy-related tumors that occur when cells in the womb start to proliferate uncontrollably. These tumors arise from trophoblasts, the cells that form the placenta. GTD can range from benign to malignant and can sometimes simulate pregnancy.
causes: Abnormal conception with excessive placental development
Maternal ovum with no functional DNA (complete hydatidiform mole)
Dispermic fertilization of an empty ovum (complete hydatidiform mole)
Dispermic fertilization of a normal ovum (partial hydatidiform mole)
diagnosis: Tests done after miscarriage or abortion

diseases.summary: Glioblastoma is the most aggressive and common type of primary brain cancer, originating from astrocytes. It is characterized by rapid growth, infiltration, and a poor prognosis. Diagnosis is typically made through imaging (CT, MRI) and biopsy, with molecular characterization becoming increasingly important.
risk_factors: Exposure to ionizing radiation (including CT scan radiation)
Hereditary syndromes (e.g., neurofibromatosis, Li-Fraumeni syndrome, tuberous sclerosis, Turcot syndrome)
Working in petroleum refining or rubber manufacturing
Increasing age (average age at diagnosis is 64)
diagnosis: Genetic and chromosomal testing (e.g., IDH1/IDH2 mutation status, EGFR amplification, TERT promoter mutation, ATRX expression)
subtypes: Astrocytoma, IDH mutant, grade 4 (formerly secondary glioblastoma)

diseases.summary: A rare neoplasm arising from the glomus body, mainly found under the nail, on the fingertip, or in the foot. Glomus tumors are modified smooth muscle cells that control the thermoregulatory function of dermal glomus bodies. They can be benign or malignant, with malignant forms being extremely rare and often locally infiltrative.
causes: Deletions in the GLMN (glomulin) gene (familial glomangiomas)
symptoms: Lump in the neck (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
Sore in the mouth or throat (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
Sore throat that does not go away (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
Trouble swallowing (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
Hoarseness in voice (for head and neck cancer, not glomus tumor)
diagnosis: Tumor size of more than 2 centimeters (criterion for malignancy)
Subfascial or visceral location (criterion for malignancy)
Physical exam (for head and neck cancer)
Blood and/or urine tests (for head and neck cancer)
Imaging tests (for head and neck cancer)
treatments: Radiation therapy (for head and neck cancer)
Cancer immunotherapy (for head and neck cancer)
Targeted therapy (for head and neck cancer)
subtypes: Glomangiosarcomas arising in benign glomus tumors (GABG)

diseases.summary: Hairy cell leukemia (HCL) is an uncommon hematological malignancy characterized by the accumulation of abnormal B lymphocytes, known as 'hairy cells', in the bone marrow, spleen, and lymph nodes. These abnormal cells interfere with the production of normal blood cells, leading to various complications. While HCL has an indolent course, patients frequently relapse, but with treatment, life expectancy is generally comparable to the general population.
risk_factors: Male sex (HCL is more common in men)
Farming and gardening (correlates with increased risk in some studies)
Exposure to herbicides (potential risk factor extrapolated from other B-cell leukemias/lymphomas)
symptoms: Infections (due to low white blood cell count)
Fatigue (due to low red blood cell count)
Easy bleeding (due to low platelet count)
diagnosis: Complete blood count (CBC) showing low white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets
Blood smear examination for hairy cells
Flow cytometry (CD19, CD20, CD22, CD11c, CD25, CD103, FMC7 positive)
Annexin A1 and BRAF V600E mutant protein testing
treatments: Watchful waiting (for asymptomatic patients without significant cytopenia)
Splenectomy (when other therapies fail and spleen has large disease burden)
Filgrastim (to stimulate white blood cell production)

diseases.summary: Head and neck cancer is a general term for cancers that develop in the mouth, nose and sinuses, salivary glands, and throat and voice box (larynx). Most head and neck cancers are squamous cell cancers, which begin in the moist tissues lining the head and neck. The cancer cells can spread into deeper tissue as the cancer grows.
causes: Workplace exposure to certain toxic substances (e.g., asbestos, wood dust, mineral acid, sulfuric acid mists, metal dusts)
risk_factors: History of head or neck cancer
symptoms: Ulcer in the mouth that does not heal
Red or white patches in the mouth
Sore on the face or oral cavity that does not heal
Visible lumps on the outside of the neck or oral cavity
Enlarged lymph node on the outside of the neck
Progressive worsening cough or sore throat
Lump or sore in the throat or neck that does not heal
Lump in the lip, mouth, or gums
Mouth sores that do not heal
Bleeding from the mouth or numbness
Discolored patches that persist in the mouth
Numbness or paralysis of facial muscles
Inflammation of the mouth or throat (mucositis)

diseases.summary: Hemangiosarcoma is a rapidly growing, highly invasive cancer that arises from the lining of blood vessels. It occurs almost exclusively in dogs, and rarely in other animals and humans. A frequent cause of death is tumor rupture leading to rapid bleeding.
risk_factors: Spayed female dogs (higher risk for cardiac hemangiosarcoma)
Neutered dogs (higher risk compared to intact males)
symptoms: Presence of nRBC, schistocytes, and acanthocytes in blood smear
Leukocytosis with neutrophilia, left shift, and monocytosis
treatments: Surgical removal of the tumor with the affected organ (e.g., splenectomy)
Coriolus versicolor (Turkey Tail mushroom) extract (efficacy debated)

synonyms: Malignant liver cancer in infants and children
diseases.summary: Hepatoblastoma is a malignant liver cancer occurring in infants and children, composed of tissue resembling fetal liver cells, mature liver cells, or bile duct cells. It usually presents with an abdominal mass and is most commonly diagnosed during a child's first three years of life.
causes: Constitutive activation of the Wnt signaling pathway

diseases.summary: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common type of primary liver cancer in adults and is currently the most common cause of death in people with cirrhosis. It is the third leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide.
causes: Integration of HBV genome into hepatocytes' TERT promoter site
risk_factors: Hemophilia (due to coincident chronic viral hepatitis infection)
Î²-catenin activation mutation in hepatic adenoma
diagnosis: Biopsy (historically required, now often not needed if imaging is conclusive)
Liver image reporting and data system (LI-RADS)

diseases.summary: Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is a cancer that develops in the lymph system, a part of the immune system. It is characterized by the presence of multinucleated Reedâ€“Sternberg cells in the lymph nodes and affects a subgroup of white blood cells called lymphocytes. It is one of the main types of lymphoma, distinct from non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
risk_factors: Age (most common in early adulthood and late adulthood)
Large number of involved nodal sites
symptoms: Painless, swollen lymph nodes (neck, underarm, groin)
Hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of both liver and spleen)
diagnosis: Lymph node biopsy (excision biopsy with microscopic examination)
Blood tests (complete blood count, blood chemistry studies, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) test, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) test)
Imaging tests (CT scan, PET scan, MRI scan, gallium scan)
treatments: Radiation therapy (external beam radiation therapy, mantle field radiation, inverted-Y field radiation, total nodal irradiation)
Targeted therapy (e.g., brentuximab vedotin, nivolumab, pembrolizumab)

diseases.summary: Hypopharyngeal cancer is a rare type of head and neck cancer that originates in the hypopharynx, the area where the larynx and esophagus meet. It forms in the outer layer (epithelium) of the hypopharynx and can spread into deeper tissues. Due to its location and often late diagnosis, it has a high mortality rate.
causes: Bile acids causing inflammation and DNA damage
symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes in the neck
Sore throat in one location that persists
Pain radiating from the throat to the ears
diagnosis: Physical examination (checking lymph nodes, throat inspection)

diseases.summary: Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive type of breast cancer characterized by cancer cells blocking lymph vessels in the skin of the breast, leading to a warm, red, and swollen appearance. It often presents without detectable lumps and can mimic skin inflammation like mastitis. IBC is typically diagnosed at a later stage and has a poorer prognosis than other breast cancers, though recent advances in therapy have improved survival rates.
causes: Invasion of the local lymphatic ducts
risk_factors: Radiation therapy to the breast or chest
symptoms: Unusually warm skin of the breast
Peau d'orange (dimpled appearance of breast skin)
Swelling of lymph nodes under the arm or in the neck
Breast size may seem to decrease
diagnosis: Biopsy of suspected lesions and/or skin
Genetic tests for BRCA and TP53 genes

diseases.summary: Small intestine cancer is a rare form of cancer that occurs in the small intestine. Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are a type of sarcoma that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract, including the small intestine.

Bile duct cancer, also known as cholangiocarcinoma, is a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts. The bile ducts are small tubes that carry bile from the liver and gallbladder to the small intestine. Bile helps in digesting fats. Bile duct cancer can occur anywhere along the bile ducts, both inside and outside the liver.
risk_factors: Chronic inflammation of the bile ducts
symptoms: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
diagnosis: Imaging tests (e.g., CT scan, MRI, ultrasound)

diseases.summary: Breast cancer is a cancer that starts in breast tissue when cells in the breast change and grow out of control, forming a tumor. It can be 'in situ' (not spread further) or 'invasive' (spread outside the breast to nearby tissues, lymph nodes, or other parts of the body through the lymph system or blood). It is the second most common cancer in women in the United States and can rarely affect men.
causes: Genetic changes in BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes
Exposure to estrogen hormone (due to reproductive history)
Radiation therapy to the breast or chest
risk_factors: History of breast cancer or benign breast disease
Inherited risk of breast cancer (BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene changes)
Older age at first birth or never having given birth
Starting menopause at a later age
symptoms: New lump or thickening in or near the breast or in the armpit
Change in the size or shape of the breast
Dimple or puckering in the skin of the breast (orange peel appearance)
Nipple turned inward into the breast
Nipple discharge (other than breast milk, sudden, bloody, or from one breast)
Scaly, red, or swollen skin in the nipple area or the breast
Pain in any area of the breast
diagnosis: Blood chemistry tests (BMP, CMP, electrolyte panel)
Cancer staging (including other imaging tests and sentinel lymph node biopsy)

diseases.summary: Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a type of cancer that causes lesions (abnormal tissue) to grow in different parts of the body, including the skin, lymph nodes, mucous membranes, and other organs. These lesions are usually red or purple and are made of cancer cells, new blood vessels, and blood cells. KS can begin in more than one place in the body simultaneously.
causes: Human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8) also called Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV)
risk_factors: Weakened immune systems due to HIV
Weakened immune systems due to medicines taken after an organ transplant
Older men of Mediterranean or Eastern European Jewish heritage
symptoms: Red, purple, or brown skin lesions on the legs and feet
Lesions on the ankles or soles of the feet
Painful swelling due to pressure from lesions blocking lymph and blood flow
diagnosis: Imaging tests to check for spread
treatments: Adjusting dose or switching immunosuppressant medicines (for iatrogenic KS)

diseases.summary: Kidney cancer is a group of cancers that starts in the kidney. Symptoms may include blood in the urine, a lump in the abdomen, or back pain. Fever, weight loss, and tiredness may also occur. Complications can include spread to the lungs or brain.
symptoms: Palpable swollen lymph nodes in the neck
treatments: Biological therapies (everolimus, torisel, nexavar, sutent, axitinib)
related_genes: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer
subtypes: Urothelial carcinoma of the renal pelvis
Carcinoid tumor of the renal pelvis
Carcinoma of the collecting ducts of Bellini
Mucinous tubular and spindle cell carcinoma

diseases.summary: Laryngeal cancer is a type of cancer that develops in any part of the larynx (voice box). It is typically a squamous-cell carcinoma. The prognosis is affected by the location of the tumor, which is divided into three anatomical regions: the glottis, the supraglottis, and the subglottis. Laryngeal cancer can spread by direct extension, metastasis to regional cervical lymph nodes, or via the bloodstream. It is considered a rare disease.
causes: Infections by some forms of HPV
risk_factors: History of head and neck cancer
symptoms: Feeling that something is stuck in the throat
diagnosis: Palpation of the neck and supraclavicular fossa
Examination of the oral cavity and oropharynx
Endoscopic examination of the larynx, trachea, and esophagus
treatments: Surgery (partial or full removal of the tumor)

diseases.summary: Head and neck cancer is a term for cancers that develop in the mouth, nose and sinuses, salivary glands, and throat and voice box (larynx). Most head and neck cancers are squamous cell cancers, beginning in the moist tissues lining the head and neck. The cancer cells can spread into deeper tissue as the cancer grows.
risk_factors: History of head or neck cancer
Exposure to certain toxic substances at work
Radiation exposure to the head and neck
symptoms: Sore in the mouth or throat that does not heal
Painful sore in the mouth or throat
Sore throat that does not go away
Change or hoarseness in the voice

diseases.summary: Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) is a rare malignant smooth muscle tumor that can originate in various organs containing smooth muscle, most commonly the uterus and abdomen. It is a type of soft-tissue sarcoma and is more frequently diagnosed in adults. LMSs are generally resistant to chemotherapy and radiation, with surgical removal at an early stage being the most effective treatment.
causes: Genomic instability due to complex karyotypes

diseases.summary: Leukemia is a group of blood cancers that typically start in the bone marrow and result in the production of large numbers of abnormal blood cells, often referred to as blasts or leukemia cells. These abnormal cells are not fully developed and can crowd out healthy blood cells, impairing their functions. Symptoms arise from the lack of normal blood cells and can include bleeding, bruising, bone pain, fatigue, fever, and an increased susceptibility to infections. Diagnosis is usually confirmed through blood tests and bone marrow biopsies.
causes: Use of fertility drugs by mothers
risk_factors: Race (Hispanics, whites, Native Americans, Asian Americans, Alaska Natives)
Non-ionizing radiation (limited evidence for childhood leukemia)
symptoms: Petechiae (tiny red dots under the skin)
treatments: Chimeric antigen receptor T cells (CAR-T cells)

diseases.summary: Liposarcomas are a type of soft tissue sarcoma that arise from fat cells. They are the most common subtype of soft tissue sarcomas in adults. Liposarcomas can occur in various locations throughout the body, including deep and superficial tissues, as well as less accessible sites like the retroperitoneum and abdominal cavity. They are classified into five main forms: atypical lipomatous tumor/well-differentiated liposarcoma, dedifferentiated liposarcoma, myxoid liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid pleomorphic liposarcoma. While some forms are considered less aggressive, all can infiltrate locally, recur after surgery, and potentially metastasize.
causes: Genetic mutations (e.g., amplification of MDM2 and CDK4 genes)
Translocations involving FUS-DDIT3 or EWSR1-DDIT3 fusion genes (in myxoid liposarcoma)
Inactivation of RB1 tumor suppressor gene (in myxoid pleomorphic liposarcoma)
symptoms: Signs and symptoms of organ dysfunction due to infiltration
Urinary tract obstruction (due to urethral blockage)
diagnosis: Genetic findings (e.g., MDM2 or CDK4 gene overexpression, specific marker chromosomes)
treatments: Chemotherapy (e.g., doxorubicin, ifosfamide, gemcitabine, docetaxel, eribulin, trabectedin)

diseases.summary: Liver cancer is cancer that starts in the liver. It can be primary, originating in the liver, or secondary, where cancer spreads from elsewhere in the body to the liver. Primary liver cancer is a significant global health concern, ranking as the sixth-most frequent cancer and fourth-leading cause of cancer death.
risk_factors: Hepatitis B and C prevalence in geographic region
diagnosis: Blood tests (e.g., alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9), carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), cancer antigen 125 (CA125))
Medical imaging (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI scan)
Liver Imaging Reporting and Data System (LI-RADS)
treatments: Targeted therapy (e.g., sorafenib, atezolizumab, nivolumab, pembrolizumab, regorafenib)
Ablation therapy (percutaneous ablation, radiofrequency ablation, microwave ablation, cryotherapy)
Antiviral drugs (for hepatitis B and C)

diseases.summary: Lung cancer is a malignant tumor that originates in the tissues of the lungs, typically in the cells lining the air passages. It is the leading cause of cancer death worldwide. The disease is primarily caused by genetic damage to lung cells, often induced by inhaling toxic substances like cigarette smoke. Damaged cells multiply uncontrollably, forming tumors that can spread within the lungs and metastasize to other parts of the body, impairing lung function and eventually leading to death if untreated. There are two main types: small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), which differ in their growth patterns and treatment responses.
causes: Genetic damage to DNA of lung cells
Indoor air pollution (burning wood, charcoal, crop residue)
Inactivation of p53 tumor suppressor gene
Inactivation of RB tumor suppressor gene
Loss of tumor suppressor genes on chromosome 3
risk_factors: Radiation therapy to the breast or chest
High consumption of nitrosamines and nitrites
Being overweight (possibly due to smoking-related lower body weight)
Older age (average age at diagnosis is 70)
Male sex (historically, but varies by geography)
symptoms: Swelling in the face and/or veins in the neck (superior vena cava syndrome)
Horner's syndrome (drooping eyelid, constricted pupil, decreased sweating on one side of the face)
Leukoerythroblastosis (immature cells in the blood, with bone marrow metastasis)
Pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen (with liver metastases)
Hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy (nail clubbing, joint soreness, skin thickening)
Autoimmune deterioration of cerebellum, limbic system, or brainstem
Paraneoplastic blood clotting (migratory venous thrombophlebitis, clots in the heart, disseminated intravascular coagulation)
diagnosis: Histological examination of biopsy by a pathologist
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain
treatments: Surgery (tumor removal, lobectomy, wedge resection, segmentectomy, pneumonectomy)
Chemotherapy (cisplatin, carboplatin, etoposide, irinotecan, topotecan, lurbinectedin, paclitaxel, docetaxel, vinorelbine, gemcitabine, pemetrexed)

Targeted therapy (EGFR inhibitors: osimertinib, erlotinib, gefitinib, afatinib, dacomitinib; ALK inhibitors: crizotinib, alectinib, brigatinib, ceritinib, lorlatinib; MET inhibitors: capmatinib, tepotinib; BRAF inhibitors: dabrafenib; MEK inhibitors: trametinib; ROS1 inhibitors: crizotinib, lorlatinib, entrectinib; NTRK inhibitors: entrectinib, larotrectinib; RET inhibitors: selpercatinib)
Immunotherapy (immune checkpoint inhibitors: durvalumab, pembrolizumab, atezolizumab, nivolumab plus ipilimumab)
Neuropathic agents (anticonvulsants, tricyclic antidepressants, serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors)

diseases.summary: Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare cancer that occurs in long-standing cases of primary or secondary lymphedema, typically in the upper or lower extremities. It is believed to arise from endothelial cells and may be more accurately referred to as angiosarcoma.
risk_factors: Post-mastectomy status (especially >5 years survival with severe lymphedema)
symptoms: Tender skin nodule in the extremity
Extensive necrotic focus involving skin and subcutaneous tissue
treatments: Chemotherapy (if metastatic disease is suspected or present)

diseases.summary: Lymphoma is a group of blood and lymph tumors that develop from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. It is a broad category encompassing many subtypes, with the two main classifications being non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) and Hodgkin lymphoma (HL). Lymphomas are part of the broader group of tumors of hematopoietic and lymphoid tissues.
causes: Epsteinâ€“Barr virus infection (risk factor for Hodgkin lymphoma)
Human T-lymphotropic virus infection (risk factor for non-Hodgkin lymphomas)
Autoimmune diseases (risk factor for non-Hodgkin lymphomas)
Immunosuppressant medications (risk factor for non-Hodgkin lymphomas)
Epstein-Barr virus (responsible for development/progression of EBV-associated lymphoproliferative diseases)
risk_factors: Family history of the disease (Hodgkin lymphoma)
Eating large amounts of red meat (may increase risk)
Weakened immune system (from HIV infection, certain drugs or medication)
Male sex (implicit in some epidemiological data)
symptoms: B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss)
treatments: Chemotherapy (e.g., ABVD regimen, BEACOPP, CHOP, R-CHOP)
Targeted therapy (e.g., rituximab, chimeric antigen receptor T cell therapies)
Plasmapheresis (for non-Hodgkin lymphomas with protein buildup)
Bone marrow or stem cell transplant (including autologous stem cell transplantation)
Physical exercises (for adult patients with hematological malignancies)
subtypes: Large B cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
Diffuse large B cell lymphoma associated with chronic inflammation
Fibrin-associated diffuse large B cell lymphoma
Extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma, nasal type
Peripheral T cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
Systemic T cell lymphoma of childhood

diseases.summary: Male breast cancer (MBC) is a cancer that originates in the breasts of males. It accounts for less than 1% of new breast cancer cases worldwide. Knowledge of MBC is less extensive than for female breast cancer due to its lower incidence and exclusion from large-scale studies. Many evaluation and treatment strategies are adopted from female breast cancer, but MBC has distinct features.
causes: High estrogen levels relative to androgen levels
Consumption of hormonal drugs for gender reassignment therapy
risk_factors: Radiation exposure to the chest or entire body
Long-term exposure to high temperatures (e.g., blast furnaces, steel works, rolling mills)
Testicular dysfunction (e.g., undescended testes, congenital inguinal hernia, orchitis)
Gynecomastia (historically considered, but not established in recent work)
symptoms: Skin lesion such as an ulcer
Enlargement or masses in axillary lymph nodes (indicating metastasis)
diagnosis: Physical examination (measuring lump size, checking lymph nodes)
Medical imaging (ultrasonography, mammography, CT scans, magnetic resonance imaging, positron-emission tomography, scintimammography, single-photon emission computed tomography)
Testing for estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), androgen receptor (AR), and HER2/neu receptor expression
subtypes: Papillary carcinomas of the breast (in situ, encapsulated, solid-papillary, invasive)
Invasive cribriform carcinoma of the breast

diseases.summary: Eye cancer refers to various types of malignant tumors that develop in or around the eye. Common types include melanoma of the eye and retinoblastoma, a cancer of the retina that primarily affects children.
symptoms: A visible mass or growth on the eye

diseases.summary: Malignant mesothelioma is a rare cancer that affects the mesothelium, a thin layer of tissue that lines the chest cavity, abdominal cavity, and heart.

A malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) is a rare form of cancer of the connective tissue surrounding peripheral nerves, classified as a sarcoma. It is one of the most common non-rhabdomyosarcoma soft tissue sarcomas in the pediatric population.
causes: Loss of heterozygosity on the 17p chromosome
Mutation in the p53 tumor suppressor gene
symptoms: Difficulty in moving the extremity with the tumor
Soreness localized to the tumor area or extremity
Pain or discomfort (numbness, burning, pins and needles)

diseases.summary: Malignant Rhabdoid Tumor (MRT) is a rare and aggressive type of cancer that primarily affects infants and young children. It is characterized by the presence of rhabdoid cells, which are large cells with abundant cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei. MRT can occur in various parts of the body, including the kidney, brain, liver, and soft tissues. The prognosis for MRT is generally poor due to its aggressive nature and tendency to metastasize early.
causes: Genetic mutations in the SMARCB1 gene (also known as INI1 or BAF47)
risk_factors: Inherited mutations in the SMARCB1 gene
symptoms: Abdominal mass or swelling (if in the kidney)
Neurological symptoms (e.g., seizures, irritability, developmental delay) if in the brain
Pain or swelling in affected areas
diagnosis: Imaging studies (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI) to detect tumors
Biopsy of the tumor for histological examination
Genetic testing to detect SMARCB1 mutations
subtypes: Malignant Rhabdoid Tumor of the Kidney (RTK)
Atypical Teratoid/Rhabdoid Tumor (AT/RT) of the central nervous system

diseases.summary: Mediastinal germ cell tumors are tumors that derive from germ cell rest remnants in the mediastinum. They are uncommon, representing only 3 to 10% of tumors originating in the mediastinum. Malignant mediastinal tumors are usually symptomatic at the time of diagnosis and cause symptoms by compressing or invading adjacent structures.
causes: Abnormal migration of germ cells during embryogenesis
Widespread distribution of germ cells to multiple sites during normal embryogenesis
symptoms: Compression of adjacent structures (lungs, pleura, pericardium, chest wall)
Invasion of adjacent structures (lungs, pleura, pericardium, chest wall)
diagnosis: CT of the chest and abdomen
Determination of serum levels of HCG
Determination of serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein
Biopsy (examination of tissue, cells, or fluids)
treatments: Chemotherapy using bleomycin, etoposide and cisplatin (for pure mediastinal seminomas)
Chemotherapy following surgical resection (for nonseminomatous germ cell tumors)

diseases.summary: Medullary thyroid cancer is a form of thyroid carcinoma originating from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland, which produce the hormone calcitonin. It is the third most common type of thyroid cancer, accounting for about 3% of all cases. Approximately 25% of MTC cases are genetic, caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, and can be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). Sporadic MTC accounts for the remaining 75% of cases.
causes: Somatic mutation of the RET proto-oncogene (sporadic)
risk_factors: Genetic conditions, including multiple endocrine neoplasia
Family history of thyroid cancer or thyroid disease
Exposure to certain types of radiation
symptoms: Hoarseness or other changes to voice
diagnosis: Fine needle aspiration of thyroid lesion
Microscopic examination of amyloid stroma with hyperplasia of parafollicular cells
treatments: Total thyroidectomy with bilateral neck dissection
Radioactive iodine therapy (not for medullary type)
subtypes: Medullary thyroid cancer associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A
Medullary thyroid cancer associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B

diseases.summary: Medulloblastoma is a common type of primary malignant brain cancer in children, originating in the cerebellum or posterior fossa. It is an invasive, rapidly growing tumor that spreads through cerebrospinal fluid and can metastasize to the brain and spinal cord. Historically classified as a PNET, it is now recognized as distinct.
causes: WNT tumors originate from the lower rhombic lip of the brainstem
SHH tumors originate from the external granular layer
Cerebellar stem cells prevented from dividing and differentiating
Mutations in Patched, Sufu, Smoothened, or other genes in the Sonic Hedgehog pathway
Amplification of the Sonic Hedgehog pathway
Mutations in CTNNB1, PTCH1, MLL2, SMARCA4, DDX3X, CTDNEP1, KDM6A, and TBR1
Disrupted MYC, Notch, BMP, and TGF-Î² signaling pathways
diagnosis: T1- and T2-weighted MRI with heterogeneous enhancement
Location adjacent to and extension into the fourth ventricle
Histology: solid, pink-gray, well circumscribed, very cellular, high mitotic activity, little cytoplasm, tendency to form clusters and rosettes
Ruling out atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumor
treatments: Maximal surgical removal of the tumor

diseases.summary: Melanoma is a type of cancer that develops from melanocytes, the cells that produce melanin. It most commonly occurs in the skin but can also develop in the mouth, intestines, or eye. It is considered the most dangerous type of skin cancer.
causes: Ultraviolet light (UV) exposure from the sun or tanning devices
Mutations in BRAF genes (V600E or V600K)
Mutations in RAS genes (NRAS, HRAS, KRAS)
Loss-of-function mutations in tumor suppressor genes (NF1, TP53, CDKN2A)
Kinase fusions (BRAF, RAF1, ALK, RET, ROS1, NTRK1, NTRK3, MET)
risk_factors: Low levels of skin pigment melanin
Dysplastic nevus syndrome (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma - FAMMM)
Exposure to UV radiation from tanning beds
Multiple atypical nevi or dysplastic nevi
Male sex (in the US, occurs 1.6 times more often in men than women)
symptoms: Changes in a mole (increase in size, irregular edges, change in color, itchiness, skin breakdown)
Appearance of a new lump on the skin (nodular melanoma)
Itching, ulceration, or bleeding of a mole
Elevated above the skin surface (nodular melanoma)
diagnosis: LDH levels (may be elevated in metastatic melanoma)
treatments: Testing nearby lymph nodes for spread
Targeted therapy (BRAF inhibitors, MEK inhibitors, C-Kit inhibitors, NRAS inhibitors)
Genetically altered autologous lymphocytes with T cell receptors (TCRs)
subtypes: Melanoma with features of a Spitz nevus

diseases.summary: Meningioma is a typically slow-growing tumor that forms from the meninges, the membranous layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord. They can be benign, atypical, or malignant. Most cases are sporadic, but some are familial. They are more common in women and older adults. Meningiomas represent about 30% of brain tumors in adults.
causes: Radiation exposure (e.g., radiation therapy, atomic bomb survivors, dental X-rays)
symptoms: Changes in ability to talk, hear, or see
diagnosis: Medical imaging (CT scan, MRI with gadolinium)
Lumbar puncture (to obtain spinal fluid, CSF protein levels may be elevated)
Dural tail sign on contrast-enhanced MRI
subtypes: Benign (Grade I) - meningothelial, fibrous, transitional, psammomatous, angioblastic
Atypical (Grade II) - chordoid, clear cell, atypical

diseases.summary: Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is a rare, aggressive type of skin cancer that begins in the Merkel cells, which are found in the epidermis of the skin. It often appears as a firm, painless, flesh-colored or bluish-red nodule, most commonly on sun-exposed areas of the body.
risk_factors: Weakened immune system (e.g., due to HIV, organ transplant, or certain medications)
History of other skin cancers (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma)
symptoms: Firm, painless, flesh-colored or bluish-red nodules
Most commonly on sun-exposed areas (face, head, neck, arms)
diagnosis: Imaging tests (CT scan, PET scan, MRI) to check for spread

diseases.summary: Mesothelioma is a type of cancer that develops from the mesothelium, the thin layer of tissue lining internal organs. It most commonly affects the lining of the lungs and chest wall, but can also occur in the lining of the abdomen, heart sac, or testis sac. The disease is strongly linked to asbestos exposure, with symptoms often appearing decades after exposure.
causes: Irradiation of the chest or abdomen
risk_factors: Occupational exposure to asbestos (mining, production, working with asbestos products)
Living near naturally occurring asbestos deposits
Exposure to talc (near mines or mills)
Paraoccupational secondary exposure (family members of asbestos workers)
symptoms: Swelling of the neck or face
Cardiac symptoms (constrictive pericarditis, heart failure, pulmonary embolism, cardiac tamponade)
Blood clots in arteries of the lungs (pulmonary embolism)
treatments: Chemotherapy (cisplatin, pemetrexed, raltitrexed, gemcitabine, vinorelbine, carboplatin, adriamycin)
Multimodality therapy (combination of surgery, radiation, chemotherapy)

diseases.summary: Mucosal melanoma is a rare condition characterized by a melanoma of the mucous membranes, associated with a worse prognosis than skin melanomas.
subtypes: Melanoma of the head and neck

diseases.summary: Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) encompasses several distinct syndromes featuring tumors of endocrine glands, each with its own characteristic pattern. Tumors can be benign or malignant. MEN syndromes are inherited as autosomal dominant disorders.
diagnosis: Genetic testing for MEN1 gene mutations
Genetic testing for RET oncogene mutations

diseases.summary: Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell that normally produces antibodies. It is characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells, which can lead to various complications affecting bones, kidneys, blood, and the immune system. While generally incurable, it is treatable with remissions possible.
causes: Malignant transformation from monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)
Chromosomal translocations involving immunoglobulin heavy chain gene and oncogenes
Dysregulated methylation patterns leading to oncogene activation and tumor suppressor gene repression
Abnormal histone modifications caused by dysregulation of polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2)
risk_factors: Certain chemicals (aromatic hydrocarbon solvents like benzene, toluene, xylene)
Occupational exposure (firefighting, hairdressing, agricultural and industrial work)
Immunodeficiency (due to HIV/AIDS, organ transplantation, rheumatoid arthritis) for EBV association
symptoms: Loss of bowel or bladder control
Mouth symptoms (pain, numbness, swelling, jaw expansion, tooth mobility, radiolucency)
CRAB criteria (Calcium elevation, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, Bone lesions)
diagnosis: Blood tests (Complete blood count, serum protein electrophoresis, quantitative immunoglobulin measurements, serum free light chain assay, beta-2 microglobulin)
Urine tests (protein electrophoresis, Bence Jones protein detection)
Bone marrow biopsy (to assess percentage of plasma cells)
Medical imaging (skeletal survey, MRI, CT scan)
Monoclonal spike (m-spike) in serum protein electrophoresis
Bone lesions (lytic lesions, punched-out lesions, osteoporosis with compression fractures)
treatments: Chemotherapy (e.g., melphalan, prednisone, bortezomib-based regimens, lenalidomide-dexamethasone)
Targeted therapy (e.g., proteasome inhibitors, immunomodulatory agents, monoclonal antibodies)
Stem cell transplant (autologous hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation - ASCT, allogeneic stem-cell transplantation)
CAR-T cell therapy (e.g., idecabtagene vicleucel, ciltacabtagene autoleucel)
Bispecific T-cell engagers (BITE) / Bispecific antibodies (e.g., teclistamab, talquetamab)
Supportive care (red blood cell transfusions, erythropoietin)

diseases.summary: Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS) are a group of blood cancers in which immature blood cells in the bone marrow do not mature or become healthy blood cells and thus cannot do their jobs. In MDS, the bone marrow produces blood cells that are abnormal or immature (dysplastic) and unable to function properly. These cells may also die in the bone marrow or soon after entering the bloodstream. As a result, there are often not enough healthy blood cells to meet the body's needs.
risk_factors: Certain genetic conditions (e.g., Fanconi anemia, Down syndrome)
symptoms: Petechiae (tiny red spots under the skin)

diseases.summary: Myelofibrosis is a rare bone marrow cancer that affects the production of blood cells. It is characterized by the scarring of the bone marrow, which impairs its ability to produce normal blood cells. This can lead to anemia, low platelet counts, and an enlarged spleen.

Myxofibrosarcoma (MFS) is a rare but common soft tissue sarcoma, often developing in elderly individuals. It is characterized by high recurrence rates, a tendency to progress to higher grades, and potential for metastasis. The epithelioid variant is particularly aggressive.
risk_factors: Older age (fifth to seventh decades of life)
symptoms: Painless, slowly enlarging masses in muscle, skin, or non-cutaneous areas
Tumor located in extremity (usually lower extremity)
Tumor located in head and neck areas
Tumor presenting in multiple sites concurrently
diagnosis: Presence of pseudo-lipoblasts in a myxoid sarcoma-like background
treatments: Chemotherapy (anthracycline, Ifosfamide, gemcitabine, paclitaxel, adriamycin, dacarbazine)

diseases.disease_name: Nasal cavity and paranasal sinus cancer
diseases.summary: Cancer of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses is rare. The paranasal sinuses are small hollow spaces around the nose lined with mucus-producing cells. The nasal cavity is the passageway behind the nose for air to reach the throat.
symptoms: Symptoms can be like those of infections
diagnosis: Lighted tube-like instruments that look inside the nose

synonyms: Cancer of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses
diseases.summary: Cancer of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses is rare. The paranasal sinuses are small hollow spaces around the nose lined with mucus-producing cells. The nasal cavity is the passageway behind the nose for air to reach the throat. Early symptoms may be absent, and later symptoms can resemble those of infections.
diagnosis: Lighted tube-like instruments to look inside the nose

diseases.summary: Throat cancer is a type of head and neck cancer that can affect different parts of the throat, including the oropharynx, hypopharynx, nasopharynx, and larynx (voice box).
symptoms: Sore throat that does not go away
Pain or ringing in the ears

diseases.summary: Wilms tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children. It is the most common kidney cancer in children.

Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer that forms in certain types of nerve tissue, most frequently starting from one of the adrenal glands but can also develop in the head, neck, chest, abdomen, or spine. It is the most common cancer in babies and the third-most common cancer in children.
causes: Genetic mutation occurring in the first trimester of pregnancy
Germline mutations in the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene
Germline mutations in the PHOX2B gene
Germline mutations in the KIF1B gene
Duplicated segments of the LMO1 gene
Copy-number variation within the NBPF10 gene
Excessively expressed miRNAs in 1p-deleted neuroblastoma cells
risk_factors: Parental factors around conception and during gestation
Occupation (exposure to chemicals in specific industries)
Use of medicinal drugs during pregnancy
Exposure to infection early in life
Use of hormones and fertility drugs
symptoms: Lump in the abdomen, neck, or chest
Painless, bluish lump under the skin
Inability to stand, crawl, or walk
diagnosis: Elevated levels of catecholamines or their metabolites in urine or blood (dopamine, homovanillic acid (HVA), vanillylmandelic acid (VMA))
Microscopy (small, round, blue tumor cells, Homer Wright pseudorosettes)
International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) classification system
International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System (INRGSS)
Imaging tests (x-rays, CT scan, ultrasound, MRI)
treatments: Immunotherapy with anti-GD2 monoclonal antibody therapy (dinutuximab)
High-dose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell rescue

diseases.summary: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) are neoplasms that arise from cells of the endocrine and nervous systems. They can occur in various locations, most commonly in the intestine, pancreas, or lungs. NETs share common features such as secretory granules and the production of biogenic amines and polypeptide hormones. They are classified by tumor grade and anatomical origin, with subtypes ranging from well-differentiated to poorly differentiated carcinomas.
causes: Genetic mutations (implicit in inherited familial syndromes like MEN1, MEN2, VHL, neurofibromatosis type 1, tuberous sclerosis, Carney complex)
risk_factors: Inherited familial syndromes (MEN1, MEN2, VHL, neurofibromatosis type 1, tuberous sclerosis, Carney complex)
diagnosis: Positron emission tomography (PET) with Gallium-68 receptor PET-CT
Immunohistochemistry for neuroendocrine markers (chromogranins, synaptophysin, PGP9.5, INSM1)
treatments: Chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin with etoposide, doxorubicin with streptozocin and fluorouracil)
subtypes: Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (LCNEC)
Extrapulmonary small cell carcinomas (ESCC or EPSCC)

diseases.summary: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is a group of blood cancers that includes all types of lymphomas except Hodgkin lymphomas. It is largely a systemic illness, unlike Hodgkin lymphoma which spreads contiguously. NHL can be slow-growing or fast-growing.
causes: Lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell)

diseases.summary: Oligodendrogliomas are a type of glioma believed to originate from oligodendrocytes or glial precursor cells. They primarily occur in adults but are also found in children, comprising about 5% of all central nervous system tumors. They are characterized by specific genetic alterations, including IDH mutations and 1p/19q co-deletion, which are associated with chemosensitivity and improved prognosis.
causes: NJDS gene mutation (69% correlation in one study)
Irradiation of pituitary adenoma (single case report)
symptoms: Headaches associated with increased intracranial pressure
Neurological deficits (e.g., visual loss, motor weakness, cognitive decline)
diagnosis: Molecular diagnostics (e.g., IDH mutation testing, 1p/19q co-deletion analysis)
treatments: Symptomatic treatment (anticonvulsants for seizures, steroids for brain swelling)

diseases.summary: Oral cancer is a cancer of the lining of the lips, mouth, or upper throat. It is a type of head and neck cancer, and most oral cancers are squamous cell cancers that begin in the flat cells covering the surfaces of the mouth, tongue, and lips. The cancer cells can spread into deeper tissue as the cancer grows.
risk_factors: History of head or neck cancer
Over consumption of canned food (in cats)
Chronic oral graft-versus-host disease (in humans after HSCT)
symptoms: Painless red or white patch in the mouth
Thickening, ulceration, and growth of a mouth patch
Persistent crusting ulcer on the lip that does not heal
New lumps or bumps in the neck
Numbness in the mouth or lips
Bleeding, pain, or numbness in the lip or mouth
Dentures that no longer fit well
Trouble moving the mouth or jaw
Sore throat or feeling that something is caught in the throat
Rough patch with ulceration and a raised border
Crusting and dry ulcer on the lip
diagnosis: Physical exam of the lips and mouth
subtypes: Metastatic cancers (from distant sites to the mouth)

diseases.summary: Oropharyngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer that affects the oral cavity and the part of the throat including the base of the tongue, tonsils, soft palate, and pharyngeal walls. It can grow locally and spread to other parts of the body. It is classified into HPV-positive and HPV-negative types.
causes: Oral human papillomavirus infection (for HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancer)
Use of alcohol (for HPV-negative oropharyngeal cancer)
Use of tobacco (for HPV-negative oropharyngeal cancer)
risk_factors: Performing open-mouthed kissing or oral/mouth-genital sex on a person with a human papillomavirus infection
Diet low in fruit and vegetables
symptoms: Sore throat that persists for over 2 weeks
Lump in the back of the throat or mouth
diagnosis: Biopsy of observed abnormal tissue in the throat
Genetic and chromosomal testing (for P53 mutation and CDKN2A mutations)
Staging according to appearance of abnormal cells on biopsy, dimensions, and extent of abnormal cells

diseases.summary: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that originates from bone-forming cells.
