It is the most common primary bone cancer in children and young adults, and also occurs in the elderly, often associated with underlying bone pathology like Paget's disease. It can also arise from soft tissues (extraskeletal osteosarcoma).
causes: Infestation with the parasite Spirocerca lupi (esophageal osteosarcoma)
risk_factors: Hereditary predisposition (e.g., in St. Bernard dogs)
Exposure to ionizing radiation (implicit from leukemia causes, though not explicitly stated for osteosarcoma)
Prior chemotherapy (implicit from leukemia causes, though not explicitly stated for osteosarcoma)
symptoms: Swelling or a lump near the affected bone
Easy bruising or bleeding (general cancer symptom)
Swollen lymph nodes or spleen (general cancer symptom)
diagnosis: CT scan (for bony anatomy, cortex integrity, fracture, ossification, calcification)
MRI scan (for soft tissue and medullary cavity)
Symmetrical widening of the periodontal ligament space (in jaw osteosarcoma)
Genetic and chromosomal testing (implicit from related genes)
treatments: Osteoclast inhibitors (e.g., alendronate, pamidronate) for pain and fracture risk reduction
Filgrastim or pegfilgrastim (for white blood cell and neutrophil counts)
Radiation therapy (mentioned in clinical trials context)

diseases.summary: Ovarian cancer is a cancerous tumor that forms in the tissues of an ovary. The ovaries are a pair of female reproductive glands that make eggs and female hormones. Cancer is a disease in which abnormal cells in the body grow out of control and form a tumor.
risk_factors: Inherited changes in BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes
Certain other genetic conditions (e.g., Lynch syndrome)
symptoms: Pain, swelling, or pressure in the abdomen or pelvis
Sudden or frequent urge to urinate

diseases.summary: Ovarian cancer is a cancerous tumor that forms in the tissues of an ovary. The ovaries are a pair of female reproductive glands that make eggs and female hormones.
risk_factors: Inherited changes in BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes
symptoms: Pain, swelling, or pressure in the abdomen or pelvis
Sudden or frequent urge to urinate

diseases.summary: Pancreatic cancer is a group of cancers that begin in the cells of the pancreas. Small precancerous neoplasms for many pancreatic cancers are being detected at greatly increased rates by modern medical imaging. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PanNETs) are a type of pancreatic cancer that arises from the hormone-producing cells of the pancreas.
treatments: Targeted therapies (e.g., inhibition of growth factors)

diseases.summary: Pancreatoblastoma is a rare type of pancreatic cancer that mainly occurs in childhood and has a relatively good prognosis. It is characterized by the presence of squamoid nests and typically presents with locally advanced or metastatic disease.
diagnosis: Histopathology showing acinar, ductal, or neuroendocrine differentiation
Tumor hypercellularity with lobules separated by fibrotic bands

diseases.summary: A rare neuroendocrine neoplasm that can develop at various body sites. When found in the adrenal gland, they are called pheochromocytomas. They are rare tumors with an incidence of about 1 in 300,000. Long-term follow-up is recommended for all individuals with paraganglioma as there is no test to distinguish benign from malignant tumors.
causes: Mutations of the genes for succinate dehydrogenase (SDHD, SDHA, SDHC, SDHB)
Mutations of SDHB gene (familial adrenal pheochromocytoma and extra-adrenal paraganglioma)
Mutations of SDHAF2, VHL, NF1, TMEM127, MAX and SLC25A11 genes
Chromaffin-negative glomus cells derived from embryonic neural crest
symptoms: Ipsilateral weakness of upper trapezius and sternocleiodomastoid muscles

diseases.summary: Parathyroid cancer is a rare malignancy of the parathyroid glands. It is often associated with hypercalcemia and can lead to bone and kidney problems.
related_genes: MEN1 gene (associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type I)
CASR gene (associated with Hyperparathyroidism-jaw tumor syndrome)

diseases.summary: Penile cancer is a cancer that develops in the skin or tissues of the penis. It is a rare cancer in developed nations but more common in developing countries. Around 95% of penile cancers are squamous-cell carcinomas.
risk_factors: Psoriasis treated with UV light and psoralen
symptoms: Ulcer or sore on the skin of the penis
Redness and irritation on the penis
Skin thickening on the glans or inner foreskin

diseases.summary: Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal gland that produces excess catecholamines, leading to symptoms such as hypertension, headaches, and palpitations. It can also occur outside the adrenal glands as a paraganglioma. While often benign, a small percentage can be malignant. Diagnosis relies on biochemical tests and imaging, and treatment typically involves surgical removal of the tumor.
causes: RET proto-oncogene (p.C634W) associated with Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2
symptoms: Episodic fits of pain concentrated in the abdomen
Hectic flush distinctly marked on each cheek
diagnosis: Incidental imaging (computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging)
Biochemical tests (catecholamine blood test, catecholamines - urine)
treatments: Treatment for progressive metastatic pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas (e.g., (177)Lu-DOTATATE)

diseases.summary: Pituitary tumors are abnormal growths that develop in the pituitary gland, a small gland located at the base of the brain. These tumors can be benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous). They can affect hormone production, leading to various health problems.
treatments: Surgery (implied by treatment options for subtypes)

diseases.summary: Plasma cell leukemia (PCL) is a plasma cell dyscrasia, a malignant degeneration of plasma cells. It is the most aggressive form of plasma cell malignancies, occurring either primarily or secondary to multiple myeloma. PCL is a serious, life-threatening, and therapeutically challenging disease.
causes: Development of excessively high number of genetic abnormalities in plasma cells or their precursor B cells and plasmablasts
Acquired genetic abnormalities including gene mutations, single nucleotide polymorphisms, deletions and duplications of gene parts or chromosomes, translocations, and changes in gene expression
Abnormalities affecting Wnt signaling pathway, cell cycle regulation, RNA metabolism, protein folding, and cell adherence
symptoms: High levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase
diagnosis: Presence of >2 billion plasma cells per liter of blood
Presence of >20% of nucleated blood cells being plasma cells
Flow cytometry immunophenotyping of blood cells to detect clonal phenotypes of plasma cells (e.g., CD138+, CD38+, CD19âˆ’, CD45+/- phenotype)
treatments: VCMP regimen (vincristine, carmustine, melphalan, prednisone alternating with vincristine, carmustine, doxorubicin, prednisone)

diseases.summary: Lung cancer is cancer that forms in tissues of the lung, usually in the cells that line the air passages. It is the leading cause of cancer death in both men and women.
risk_factors: Radiation therapy to the breast or chest
Radon in the home or workplace
Certain imaging tests such as CT scans
Living in areas with higher levels of air pollution
symptoms: A cough that doesn't go away or gets worse over time
Weight loss for no known reason
Swelling in the face and/or veins in the neck
diagnosis: Imaging tests (chest x-ray, chest CT scan)
Genetic testing for gene changes (variants) in cancer cells (for small-cell lung cancer)

diseases.summary: Ovarian cancer is a cancerous tumor that forms in the tissues of an ovary. It is a group of blood cancers that start in the bone marrow and produce large numbers of abnormal white blood cells.
risk_factors: Inherited BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene changes
symptoms: Pain in the abdomen or pelvis
Swelling in the abdomen or pelvis
Feeling of pressure in the abdomen or pelvis

diseases.summary: Prostate cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the prostate, a gland in the male reproductive system. It is one of the most common cancers in men and often grows slowly, but can sometimes grow quickly and spread to other parts of the body, making it serious.
causes: Accumulation of genetic mutations in prostate cells
Gene fusion between TMPRSS2 and ERG
Defective DNA damage repair genes (e.g., p53, RB1, BRCA2, ATM)
Aberrant activation of the Wnt signaling pathway
risk_factors: Dietary factors (high dietary fats, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, calcium)
symptoms: Trouble urinating (frequent urination, slow or weak urine stream)
Pain in lower back, hips, or pelvis
diagnosis: Imaging tests (ultrasound, MRI, CT scans, PSMA scan, bone scintigraphy)
treatments: Radical prostatectomy (surgery to remove the prostate)
Radiation therapy (intensity-modulated radiation therapy, brachytherapy, external beam radiotherapy)
Targeted therapy (e.g., Lu-177 PSMA, PARP inhibitors, immune checkpoint inhibitors)
Supportive care (pain management, treatment for lymphedema, psychological interventions)

diseases.summary: Retinoblastoma is a rare, rapidly developing cancer of the immature cells of the retina, the light-detecting tissue of the eye. It is the most common primary malignant intraocular cancer in children, with most cases detected in those under 3 years old. While survival rates are high in developed countries, vision loss or eye removal can occur.
causes: Congenital mutation in the RB1 gene on chromosome 13 (13q14)
Somatic amplification of the MYCN oncogene
risk_factors: Presence of human papilloma virus sequences (in developing countries)
symptoms: Leukocoria (amaurotic cat's eye reflex, "white eye", "cat's eye")
Whitish, translucent mass in the eye
Red and irritated eye with glaucoma
diagnosis: Genetic testing for RB1 gene mutations
subtypes: Trilateral retinoblastoma (retinoblastoma concurrent with pineoblastoma or other midline supratentorial PNETs)

diseases.summary: Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a highly aggressive form of cancer that develops from mesenchymal cells that have failed to fully differentiate into myocytes of skeletal muscle. Cells of the tumor are identified as rhabdomyoblasts. It is generally considered to be a disease of childhood, as the vast majority of cases occur in those below the age of 18. It is commonly described as one of the small-blue-round-cell tumors of childhood due to its appearance on an H&E stain. Despite being relatively rare, it accounts for approximately 40% of all recorded soft-tissue sarcomas.
symptoms: Rapidly enlarging, firm mass in the extremity
diagnosis: Immunohistochemical staining for muscle-specific proteins (myogenin, muscle-specific actin, desmin, D-myosin, myoD1)

diseases.summary: Salivary gland cancer is a group of cancers that start in the salivary glands. These glands produce saliva, which helps with digestion and keeps the mouth moist. Salivary gland cancers can occur in any of the salivary glands, but they are most common in the major salivary glands, which are located in and around the mouth and throat.
symptoms: A lump or swelling in or around the jaw, mouth, or throat
Pain in the face, jaw, or ear
Difficulty swallowing or opening the mouth
Numbness or weakness in the face
A change in the taste of food
A sore that does not heal
diagnosis: Imaging tests (e.g., CT scan, MRI, PET scan)

diseases.summary: Uterine cancer is a cancer that forms in tissues of the uterus. There are two main types: endometrial cancer, which begins in the cells lining the uterus, and uterine sarcoma, a rare, more aggressive cancer that begins in muscle or other tissues in the uterus.
risk_factors: Estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy (HRT) after menopause (for endometrial cancer)
Early menarche or late menopause (for endometrial cancer)
Tamoxifen use (for endometrial cancer and uterine sarcoma)
Family history of endometrial cancer (mother, sister, or daughter)
Past radiation therapy to the pelvis (for uterine sarcoma)

diseases.summary: Serous carcinoma is a type of cancer that originates in the serous fluid-producing cells of the body, most commonly found in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and peritoneum. It is characterized by the formation of cysts filled with a watery fluid.

Skin cancers are cancers that arise from the skin, occurring when skin cells grow uncontrollably, forming malignant tumors. They are the most commonly diagnosed form of cancer in humans, with primary causes linked to prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
causes: Prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun
UVB radiation via direct DNA damage (for BCC and SCC)
UVA radiation via indirect DNA damage (for melanoma)
Free radicals and reactive oxygen species
HPV infections (increase risk of squamous-cell skin cancer)
Deliberate exposure of sensitive skin to sunlight
risk_factors: Poor immune function (e.g., from medications or HIV/AIDS)
symptoms: Changes in the skin that do not heal
Changes in existing moles (jagged edges, enlargement, changes in color, texture, or bleeding)
Painful lesion that itches or burns
Large brownish spot with darker speckles
Raised, smooth, pearly bump on sun-exposed skin (BCC)
Small blood vessels within the tumor (telangiectasia) (BCC)
Crusting and bleeding in the center of the tumor (BCC)
Red, scaling, thickened patch on sun-exposed skin (SCC)
Firm hard nodules with a scaly top (SCC)
Mole that has changed in size, shape, color, has irregular edges, has more than one color, is itchy or bleeds (melanoma)
Pink, red or fleshy colored moles (amelanotic melanoma)
Appearance of a new mole during adulthood
Pain, itching, ulceration, redness around the site, or bleeding at the site of a mole
Rapidly growing, non-tender red, purple or skin colored bumps (Merkel cell carcinomas)
treatments: CCPDMA (Chemotherapy, Cryotherapy, Photodynamic Therapy, Dermabrasion, Medical Abortion)
Biologic immunotherapy agents (e.g., ipilimumab, pembrolizumab, nivolumab, cemiplimab)

diseases.summary: Soft tissue sarcomas are a group of cancers that arise from cells in the soft tissues of the body, such as muscle, fat, nerves, blood vessels, and deep skin tissues. Rhabdomyosarcoma is a specific type of soft tissue sarcoma that arises from muscle cells.

Stomach cancer is a malignant tumor that develops in the lining of the stomach due to abnormal cell growth. Most cases are gastric carcinomas, with subtypes like gastric adenocarcinomas. Lymphomas and mesenchymal tumors can also occur in the stomach. It is the fifth-leading type of cancer globally and the third-leading cause of cancer death.
causes: Genetic syndromes (e.g., hereditary diffuse gastric cancer)
risk_factors: Dietary factors (pickled vegetables, salted foods, processed meats, red meat)
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes
Bloating of the stomach after meals
diagnosis: Medical imaging (CT scan, PET scan, endoscopic ultrasound)
Tumor marker tests (e.g., carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen)
treatments: Surgery (gastrectomy, endoscopic mucosal resection, endoscopic submucosal dissection)
Chemotherapy (e.g., 5-fluorouracil, cisplatin, epirubicin, etoposide, docetaxel, oxaliplatin, capecitabine, irinotecan)
Targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for HER2-overexpressing cancer)
Bone marrow or stem cell transplant
subtypes: Extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas (MALT type)

diseases.summary: Testicular cancer is a cancer that develops in the testicles, which are part of the male reproductive system and are responsible for making male hormones and sperm. It is a rare cancer that most commonly affects men between the ages of 20 and 39.
causes: Genetic mutations (implied by chromosomal abnormalities in germ cell tumors)
symptoms: Dull ache in the lower abdomen
Feeling of heaviness in the scrotum
Sudden build-up of fluid in the scrotum
Shortness of breath (dyspnea) (if spread to lungs)
Coughing up blood (hemoptysis) (if spread to lungs)
Lump in the neck (if spread to lymph nodes)
diagnosis: Blood tests (for tumor markers like Alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin, LDH-1)
Inguinal orchiectomy (surgical removal of the testicle for microscopic examination)
CT scans (for staging and detecting metastases)
Pregnancy test (to detect high levels of chorionic gonadotropin)
Histology of tissue from inguinal orchiectomy
treatments: Chemotherapy (e.g., BEP protocol: Bleomycin-Etoposide-Cisplatin, EP protocol: Etoposide-Cisplatin, platinum-based drugs like cisplatin and carboplatin)
High-dose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant
Surveillance (close monitoring with regular exams and tests)

diseases.summary: A thymoma is a rare tumor originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus. It is frequently associated with neuromuscular and autoimmune disorders.

Thyroid cancer is a cancer that develops from the tissues of the thyroid gland, a small, butterfly-shaped gland in the front of the neck that produces hormones controlling metabolism. It is characterized by abnormal cell growth with the potential to spread to other parts of the body. Many cases are asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging.
causes: Mutations in genes for MenA and Men2B
risk_factors: Radiation exposure at a young age
Family history of thyroid cancer or thyroid disease
Radiation treatments to head or neck as a child
Certain genetic conditions (e.g., multiple endocrine neoplasia)
symptoms: Swelling or a lump in the neck
Feeling of something in the throat
Pain in the anterior region of the neck
diagnosis: Whole body I-131 or I-123 radioactive iodine scan
subtypes: Noninvasive follicular thyroid neoplasm with papillary-like nuclear features

diseases.summary: Urethral cancer is a rare cancer originating from the urethra. It is more common in men than women and its incidence rises after the age of 75. Around half of affected people have locally advanced disease when they first present.
risk_factors: Prolonged irritations of the urethra due to urinary catheterization
symptoms: Weak or interrupted flow of urine
Lump or thickness in the perineum or penis
Enlarged lymph nodes or pain in the groin or vaginal area

diseases.summary: Uterine sarcoma is a rare, aggressive cancer that forms in the muscle or other tissues of the uterus. It is harder to treat than endometrial cancer and can spread quickly.
risk_factors: Taking estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy (HRT) after menopause
diagnosis: T2*-weighted imaging (MRI to differentiate from leiomyomas)
Mitotic count (>10 per high power field for malignancy)
treatments: Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

diseases.summary: Vaginal cancer is a rare form of cancer that develops in the tissue of the vagina. Primary vaginal cancer originates from the vaginal tissue, most frequently squamous cell carcinoma, but primary vaginal adenocarcinoma, sarcoma, and melanoma have also been reported. Secondary vaginal cancer involves the metastasis of a cancer that originated in a different part of the body and is more common. It occurs more frequently in women over age 50, with a mean age of diagnosis of 60 years, and can often be cured if found and treated in early stages.
risk_factors: Certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV) infections
Abnormal cells in the vagina, cervix, or uterus
symptoms: Bleeding that is longer than normal
Blood in the stool or urine
Frequent or urgent need to urinate
A lump or growth in the vagina that can be felt

diseases.summary: Vulvar cancer is a rare type of cancer that forms in a woman's external genitals, called the vulva. It usually grows slowly over several years, starting as precancerous cells called vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN).
causes: Chronic inflammation or autoimmunity affecting the vulvar area
risk_factors: Prior history of pre-invasive or invasive cervical cancer
symptoms: Changes in the skin of the vulva
Redder or whiter skin color on the vulva
Rash or warts on the vulva
Sores or ulcers on the vulva

diseases.summary: Wilms tumor is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children. It is also known as nephroblastoma.
